social_posts.post_text:
The new printable guide for #theunreadshelfproject2023 is ready for you! Head over to theunreadshelf.com or my profile to get your copy.

This year, we are changing up the traditional monthly challenges. Instead, we are focusing on monthly one word prompts to guide us in our choices.

Instead of forcing our reading to fit the challenge, I want you to find the book that you NEED to read - that’s already on your shelf.

Because if there’s anything I’ve learned from the past 7 years of the Unread Shelf Project, it’s that I already have the books I need to read.

There’s lots more info on the blog, and I’ll be sharing more info as the New Year approaches.

But first I’d love to know - what’s the one word to describe the reading year you want to have in 2023?

#theunreadshelfproject #unreadshelfproject #readingchallenge #readingchallenge2023 #literarylife #literarylifestyle #readyourshelf

📎Save this post for later. If you’re new to #theunreadshelfproject2023 here are the steps to get you started.

If you love accountability and weekly check-ins, I have a free 3 week email course to walk you through each step AND the why behind each one. I am happy to get you signed up, just DM me for the link.

If you’re a pen and paper person, hop over to my website to get the free printable guide that has ALL these steps (and more!).

Want even more accountability (and fun!)? Join our Unread Shelf Community. Think of it as your own private book club with monthly Zoom chats - and the only assigned books are already on your shelves. ❤️

What step will be the hardest for you this year?

#theunreadshelfproject #unreadshelfproject2023 #readingchallenge #readingcommunity #2023readingchallenge #bookclubsofinstagram #unreadbooks

Literally my reading motto for 2023. ✌🏻Tap the ❤️ if you agree.

Thanks @thrifted.home.co for the reel inspo!

#readingbringsjoy #booksbringjoy #readinglife #literarylife #mybookstagram #mybookshelf #shelfies #literarylifestyle #readwhatyoulove #booktrend

We are taking things a new direction in 2023 - instead is specific reading challenges, we are embracing mood reading AND our unread shelves. How?? With one word prompts to help you lean into your own books.

I talk about why and give you all 12 prompts in today’s blog post - over on theunreadshelf.com.

I’d love to hear which word is your favorite and which one you may struggle with this year - leave a comment below.

And while you’re on the blog, don’t forget to download your free printable guide for this year!

#theunreadshelfproject2023 #unreadshelfproject2023 #readingchallenge2023 #bookloversofinstagram

Hey friends! I wanted to introduce myself to anyone who might be new around here. I’m Whitney - wife, mom to 3, and small biz owner of the online vintage shop @thrifty_whitney .

I started my own unread shelf project in 2017 when I decided to intentionally focus on reading my unfinished books. I shared my project on Bookstagram, and so many people said they had the same problem - too many unread books and tons of guilt, but feeling like they can never stop adding to their shelves.

We are now entering our 7th (!!!!) year of reading together, and I have never been more certain that this is the challenge most readers need. Especially me.

I have so many free resources available on my blog at theunreadshelf.com - if you’re not sure where to start, DM me and I’ll get you right what you need.

I’d love to hear how you found my account and what your  biggest goal is for your unread books in 2023.

#bookstagrammersunite #homelibrarygoals #myreadinglife #bookishreels #bookishaesthetic #theunreadshelfproject2023 #shelfstyle #booksandplants #booksandtea

Do you fill out your guide for the entire year now? Or wait? I never do it in advance!

Secret tip: you don’t have to pick out all 12 books for #theunreadshelfproject2023 now. If you’re a mood reader, take it a month at a time. 

For some of us, putting a book on a MUST READ list means we will NEVER read it. Call it a rebellious tendency, but if we aren’t feeling like it, we aren’t gonna read it.

Instead, trust your intuition. As you finish books and choose your next read, use the guide as a gentle nudge to look at your books from different perspectives.

The yearly goals sheet is broke down into 4-month chunks, so you can plan out small achievable goals a few at a time. This makes it WAY more likely you’ll reach them!

Follow for more reading life tips and inspiration!

#unreadshelfproject #readingtips #readsmart #readwhatyouown #readingchallenges #readingchallenge #theunreadshelfproject #howtoread #bookishinstagram

Here is the first prompt for #theunreadshelfproject2023 - COMFORT. What does this word mean to you when you think of books?

For me, it’s mid-twentieth century British women’s fiction, detective novels, and Emily St. John Mandel. 

I pulled this stack off my unread shelves as potential picks. They are mostly by authors I’ve read before. And they all feel cozy and familiar to me (even if the mystery novels may seem a bit gruesome!).

I’ve learned that planning out specific picks in advance actually means I am LESS likely to read them (see previous reel!). So hopefully a shortlist will make me feel like I have a bit more freedom in choosing my next read.

What are you choosing for this month’s challenge?

#readingchallenge #cozymystery #cozymysteries #barbarapym #britishliterature #britishlibrarycrimeclassics

Do you have a death pile? This term actually comes from the reselling world, but it occurred to me that it’s the perfect phrase to describe our piles of unread books.

You know what I’m talking about. That shelf where you plop down all your new purchases, fully intending to read them…sometime. But months go by, the shelves fill up, and your books just languish there.

This book cart is one of my death piles. I’m committed to clearing it out by April 30 (one of of my short term goals for #theunreadshelfproject2023 ). I’m reading the books, relocating them, or giving them away. But it’s time for these books to see some action.

I’d love to see your book death pile and your plan to clearing it out. You can even save this audio 📎 and make your own reel with it - it makes it super easy to see everyone’s piles together! (If you don’t want to do video, you can even just put a photo in a reel with this audio and boom! You’ve made a reel).

Let’s do this together. 🙌🏻

#deathpiledestruction #unreadshelfproject #theunreadshelfproject #theunreadshelf #unreadshelfproject2023

I’m fine, really. 🫠 Anyone else feel this? Gimme a ❤️.

A book buying ban (or pause) is NOT required for #theunreadshelfproject2023 - but for some of us, it can be REALLY helpful.

If you’re tired of using book buying as a coping mechanism or a bad habit when you’re bored, try it for a week (or month). Shop your own shelves. See if it makes a difference.

Have you ever taken a break from buying books? What happened?

Here is my reading journal for 2023…surprised? 😅

In the past, I’ve had a very detailed, graph-filled journal that tracked everything I could possibly think of when it came to my reading. But right now, I need a simple, stripped-down process. This fits the bill perfectly.

The little dots mean the books are off my unread shelf. I also enter books read on my @the.storygraph account as a back up. 

How are you tracking your reading this year?

#bookjournal #bookjournaling #readingjournal

It’s February 1, and we have a new prompt for #theunreadshelfproject2023 - and it’s COURAGE.

We all need a little courage to tackle our unread shelves, right?

And we may also need it to read the hard books - the serious ones, challenging topics, or high page counts we’ve been putting off.

Or maybe this is the month to read about courageous people. I am hoping to read a few memoirs of courageous explorers and families who faced horrific political situations - hopefully I can snag some photos tomorrow to share with you.

I’d love to hear what direction you’re taking this prompt and what you’re hoping to finish in February!

#unreadshelfproject2023 #readmyshelves #readmybooks #shelfchallenge #bookstagram2023 #bookishcommunity

March has an unusual prompt that may have you scratching your head - the word “enough”. What does that mean when it comes to your reading life? And how in the world do we choose a book based on that prompt?

“Enough” feels deeply relevant to me right now, in the thick of raising a family and a small business from the ground up - because I never feel like I HAVE enough. Time to read, or write, or even browse the library shelves. And it’s easy to get down on myself for not doing enough for my reading self (or heck, even managing to post the monthly prompt on time! 🤦🏼‍♀️).

But I’m taking time in March to recognize I do have enough.

Enough great books on my unread shelf, if I look for them.

Enough time to read, if I put my phone down.

Enough finished books on my 2023 list to make me a reader, even if the list of short - because even ONE book is enough.

I have a longer blog post up at theunreadshelf.com that dives into this more. But I’d love to hear your thoughts on how you are applying this prompt to your unread shelves in March. Where is it taking you?

#theunreadshelf #theunreadshelfproject2023 #unreadshelfproject2023 #iamareader #literarylife #literarylifestyle #enoughbooks #readyourshelf #readingchallenge2023

“Curiouser and curiouser…” (Alice in Wonderland)

In May we are exploring our shelves with curiosity! We all have books on our unread shelves that have sparked an interest. Or perhaps we find them strange or unusual (which is what I think Alice was referring to).

It’s so easy to pick up books on a whim. And there they sit. Let’s tap back into that spark and pick up the books we were curious enough to buy.

And you can also follow your interest on this one - see where your curiosity leads you in your own shelves!

(Also - apologies for never posting the April challenge. 🫣 April was a pretty intense month and I dropped the ball. Let’s make up for it by commenting twice on this post 😅).

#theunreadshelfproject2023 #unreadshelfproject2023 #theunreadshelf

Let’s kick off the summer with a new prompt to help you explore your unread shelves!

I had a lot of fun discussing this prompt in last week’s Zoom chat for the Unread Shelf Community. (Need details? Message me!)

Everyone had a slightly different take on “explore.” Just another reason I’m glad we chose open ended prompts this year!

It’s a twist on the normal summer challenge of armchair reading. But you could also read stories about explorers, or choose a topic to dive into (most of us collect books on anything that piques our interest, right?).

I have had West with the Night by Beryl Markham on my shelf for years and I think this will finally be the month I take it on vacation and read it.

How about you? Comment below with what book you’re choosing for June’s prompt!

#unreadshelfproject #theunreadshelfproject2023 #unreadshelf #readwhatyouown #exploreyourshelves #readingprompts

Do your unread books bring you joy?

Or does guilt play a bigger part in your reading life?

In July we are focusing on JOY as a prompt for diving into our unread shelves.

It’s so easy for us to be overwhelmed with fear and shame when it comes to our unread books.

But what could be more joyful for a reader than piles of possibilities? Read more in today’s blog post at theunreadshelf.com.

I’d love to hear how you’re using July’s prompt to approach your unread books in a fresh way. Comment below!

#theunreadshelfproject #theunreadshelfproject2023 #unreadshelfproject2023

Take a deep breath and think about the fact that we have made it through over half our year of the Unread Shelf Project...and get ready to slow down and IMMERSE yourself this month.

In August, we've chosen another prompt that gives you the freedom and flexibility to "choose your own adventure" with your unread books.

"Immerse" is your ticket to any number of destinations. It could mean immersing yourself in a genre, collection, author or publisher.

It could also mean choosing one book that immerses you in a world, completely taking you out of yourself and giving you new experiences and thoughts.

I am choosing August to immerse myself in my collection of books published by @persephonebooks - each one I pick up is a delight and a revelation. I am currently reading The Homemaker by Dorothy Canfield-Fisher, and I can't wait to read more of their titles.

What are you reading from your unread shelves in August?

#theunreadshelf #theunreadshelfproject #unreadshelfproject #readwhatyouown #readyourshelves #persephonebooks

I weeded out 28 books from my unread shelf today. My two questions were - would I start this tomorrow if I had time? And, is this hard to get from the library?

If “no” to both questions, it went in the donate pile. If “yes” to either, I took some time to decide. If “yes” to both, it was an easy keep.

My brain protested, “You spent money on this!!!” But that wasn’t part of my decision tree today, so I just ignored it.

It feels very freeing to pull these books from my unread list!

What questions do you ask yourself when weeding books?

As we head into 2024, I want to share some news about the Unread Shelf Project. It may not come to a surprise to you, if you've noticed my absence on the blog and Instagram.

I am stepping away from the Unread Shelf Project, and the website will be closing on February 4, 2024.

The reading community has been a huge blessing in my life through some rocky years of personal growth and changes. Managing the Project and building the community on Instagram gave me many wonderful friendships. 

It also helped me grow muscles that I am using in my new business, Thrifty Whitney, selling antiques & vintage home decor locally and online. This new business has grown along with my family.

I am so thankful for you all, who have joined in the project with enthusiasm, applied its principles, and enlarged your reading life.

The Instagram account will stay open but dormant for now. You can find me online at my website thriftywhitney.com or on my Instagram account @thrifty_whitney.

Once again, thank you for all the ways you have supported this endeavor through the years, and I wish you the best in your reading life.

A few of you have asked about our private community over on Mighty Networks - it is staying open for 2024. 🎉 I am not planning any new prompts. But many of the members love the space and find that it fills a gap for reading community they can’t find else where in their lives.

Because it’s also separate from social media, there’s a lot less noise and drama. The conversations are rich, and I have spent 99% of my Bookstagram time over there in the past year.

If you want to check it out, you can go to community.theunreadshelf.com or click my link in bio.

•Founder of #theunreadshelfproject 2017-2023
•Find me online at @thrifty_whitney 
•No new guides for 2024 - community still open for members 👇🏻
